aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Information for Piper J3C 65 in Connersville, Indiana
Piper J3C 65 is an aircraft.
N6245H is the registration number of the Piper J3C 65 aircraft.
The accident occurred in Connersville, Indiana.
The accident occurred on May 3, 2014.
The accident occurred at 15:10 local time.
The accident's defining event was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Positioning.
The accident number was CEN14CA231.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
One person suffered minor injuries in the accident.
The pilot decided to land at an en route airport to obtain fuel.
The pilot decided to land due to a stronger headwind than what was forecast for the route of flight.
The pilot made a normal landing to the north.
The pilot turned west off the runway onto the first taxi.
The pilot made another turn to the north on the taxiway that paralleled the runway.
The pilot taxied beyond a row of trees that were to the west.
The upwind wing of the airplane lifted as the pilot taxied beyond the trees.
The airplane flipped inverted after the wing lifted.
The rudder was substantially damaged.
The left front wing strut was substantially damaged.
The pilot stated he was using proper crosswind taxi technique.
The pilot was unable to keep the wing down despite using proper technique.
Wind conditions recorded at an airport 37 miles away were from 290 degrees at 16 knots gusting to 25 knots.
The pilot reported the local wind condition at the time of the accident was similar to the recorded conditions.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's inability to control the airplane while taxiing due to a strong crosswind condition.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Connersville, Indiana

## Date & Time: 
May 3, 2014, 15:10 Local

## Aircraft:
Piper J3C 65

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Positioning

## Accident Number:
CEN14CA231

## Registration:
N6245H

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 Minor

## Analysis

The pilot reported that he decided to land at an en route airport to obtain fuel due to a stronger headwind than what was forecast for his route of flight. The pilot made a normal landing to the north and turned west off the runway onto the first taxi. He then made another turn to the north on the taxiway that paralleled the runway. As he taxied beyond a row of trees that were to the west, the upwind wing of the airplane lifted and the airplane flipped inverted. The rudder and left front wing strut were substantially damaged. The pilot stated he was using proper crosswind taxi technique, but was unable to keep the wing down. The wind conditions recorded at an airport located 37 miles away from the airport where the accident occurred were from 290 degrees at 16 knots gusting to 25 knots. The pilot reported the local wind condition at the time of the accident was similar.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's inability to control the airplane while taxiing due to a strong crosswind condition.

---
